text: Agile and continuous integration. If done properly you can roll out multiple times per day. In practice there are other issues like available windows, etc

text: I may be wrong but I get the impression that maybe their test environment doesnt / cant mirror prod close enough so they are forced to test in live.

text: I think the rate of failures after release supports that view

text: I have a live system that has been in continuous improvement for 11 years. I have often rolled out to live multiple times per day. It's nowhere near as large as Betfair's eco-system (not even close), but having said that, it is a system that has turned over $1M/day at times, so failures can be expensive

elements.text: I have a live system that has been in continuous improvement for 11 years. I have often rolled out to live multiple times per day. It's nowhere near as large as Betfair's eco-system (not even close), but having said that, it is a system that has turned over $1M/day at times, so failures can be expensive

text: I think I have managed probably about 1000 updates over that time, and I have only botched it up once or twice (causing a rollback)

text: It could be worse: <https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Knight_Capital_Group#2012_stock_trading_disruption>

attachments.title: Knight Capital Group
attachments.text: The Knight Capital Group was an American global financial services firm engaging in market making, electronic execution, and institutional sales and trading. With its high-frequency trading algorithms Knight was the largest trader in U.S. equities, with a market share of 17.3% on NYSE and 16.9% on NASDAQ.  The company agreed to be acquired by Getco LLC in December 2012 after an August 2012 trading error lost $460 million.  The merger was completed in July 2013, forming KCG Holdings.

elements.text: It could be worse:

text: $460M due to a botched rollout

elements.text: $460M due to a botched rollout

text: A few months ago Tabcorp (looks after all Totes in Australia) had a 36 hour outage, starting on 10 am Saturday (carnival time)

text: Apparently a small fire in a data centre caused the fire extinguishers to go off, releasing cold Freon gas. Cold Freon gas and hot (old) circuit boards don't mix, with the obvious result. The backup system in another State was not available (cost cutting I think). 36 hours later they were back online. I wouldn't have wanted to be in IT at Tabcorp during that time

elements.text: Apparently a small fire in a data centre caused the fire extinguishers to go off, releasing cold Freon gas. Cold Freon gas and hot (old) circuit boards don't mix, with the obvious result. The backup system in another State was not available (cost cutting I think). 36 hours later they were back online. I wouldn't have wanted to be in IT at Tabcorp during that time

text: I tend not to boast about the reliability of my system lest the next day it go down and end up offline for some time. We are all only one mistake away from a disaster

elements.text: I tend not to boast about the reliability of my system lest the next day it go down and end up offline for some time. We are all only one mistake away from a disaster

text: I have stuffed up one rollout. System for processing cheques and applications for the first Telstra float/IPO (like British Telecom) in 1997 (I think). We (me and one other guy) were developing the software to link all the document imaging, cheque scanning, application entry to process $20B of applications in 4 weeks. Naturally, the client requested changes while we were live. One change that I implemented managed to zero out all application amounts for batches post my rollout. Imagine my surprise/horror when one of the data entry operators showed me a screen that had applications worth $0. And then another. And another. Managed to rollback, find the batches affected, and fix it. Not the most relaxing day of my career :joy:

elements.text: I have stuffed up one rollout. System for processing cheques and applications for the first Telstra float/IPO (like British Telecom) in 1997 (I think). We (me and one other guy) were developing the software to link all the document imaging, cheque scanning, application entry to process $20B of applications in 4 weeks. Naturally, the client requested changes while we were live. One change that I implemented managed to zero out all application amounts for batches post my rollout. Imagine my surprise/horror when one of the data entry operators showed me a screen that had applications worth $0. And then another. And another. Managed to rollback, find the batches affected, and fix it. Not the most relaxing day of my career

text: <@U021T88JD5Z> has joined the channel

Used to work in finance, we had a water cooling pipe burst above a server cage in a NYSE colo a couple of hours before US stock market open when mkt down significantly overnight. Squeeky bum time moving 100s of apps running on bare metal to different hosts before the mkt open. Some poor sod had to drive to to the cage and literally mop up the mess and turn off the power.

elements.text: Used to work in finance, we had a water cooling pipe burst above a server cage in a NYSE colo a couple of hours before US stock market open when mkt down significantly overnight. Squeeky bum time moving 100s of apps running on bare metal to different hosts before the mkt open. Some poor sod had to drive to to the cage and literally mop up the mess and turn off the power.

text: (for those wondering, in those colos, local tech won't open the cages - there is a list of approved individuals who can access the servers for IP theft reasons)
